prevtext:
\title{\bf Zero sets of Abelian Lie algebras of vector fields} 
\author{{\bf Morris W. Hirsch}
  \\ Mathematics Department\\ University of Wisconsin at
  Madison\\ University of California at Berkeley}

\maketitle


\begin{abstract}

\noindent
Assume $M$ is a $3$-dimensional real manifold without
boundary, ${\mathcal {A}}$ is an abelian Lie algebra of analytic vector fields on
$M$, and $X\in{\mathcal {A}}$.  The following result is proved:

If $K$ is a locally maximal compact set of zeroes of $X$ and
 the Poincar\'e-Hopf index of $X$ at $K$ is nonzero, there is a
point in $K$ at which all the elements of ${\mathcal {A}}$ vanish.
\end{abstract}





\tableofcontents


\section{Introduction}   {\label{{sec:intro}}}

Throughout this paper $M$ denotes a real analytic, metrizable manifold
that is connected and has finite dimension $n$, fixed at $n=3$ in the main results.  



The space of (continuous) vector fields on $M$ endowed with the
compact open topology is ${\mathcal {V}} (M)$, and ${\mathcal {V}}^r {M}$ is the subspace of
$C^r$ vector fields.  Here $r$ denotes a positive integer, $\infty$,
or ${\omega}$ (meaning analytic); this convention is abbreviated by $1\le
r\le {\omega}$.

The {\em zero set} of $X\in {\mathcal {V}} (M)$ is ${\ensuremath{\operatorname{{{\mathsf {Z}}}} (X)}}:=\{p\in M{\colon\thinspace} X_p=0\}$.
If ${\ensuremath{\operatorname{{{\mathsf {Z}}}} (X)}} ={\varnothing}$ (the empty set), $X$ is {\em nonsingular}. 
The zero set of a subset ${\mathcal {S}}\subset {\mathcal {V}} (M)$ is ${\ensuremath{\operatorname{{{\mathsf {Z}}}} ({{\mathcal {S}}})}}:=\bigcap_{X\in S}{\ensuremath{\operatorname{{{\mathsf {Z}}}} (S)}}$. 

A compact set $K\subset {\ensuremath{\operatorname{{{\mathsf {Z}}}} (X)}}$ is a {\em block of zeros} for $X$--- called
an
{\em $X$-block} for short--- if it lies in a precompact open set
$U\subset M$ whose closure ${\ensuremath{\overline{U}}}$ contains no other zeros of $X$;
such an open set is {\em isolating} for $X$, and for
$(X, K)$.

When $U$ is isolating for $X$ there is a unique maximal open
neighborhood ${\mathcal {N}}_U \subset {\mathcal {V}} (M)$ of $X$ with the following
property ({\sc Hirsch} \cite{Hirsch2015a}): 
\begin{quote} \em
If $Y\in {\mathcal {N}}_U$ has only finitely many zeros in $U$,
 the Poincar\'e-Hopf index of $Y|U$ depends only on $X$ and $K$. 
\end{quote} 
This index is an integer denoted by ${\mathsf {i}}_K (X)$, and also by ${\mathsf {i}} (X, U)$, with the latter notation implying that $U$ is isolating for
$X$.\footnote{

The index can be equivalently defined as the intersection number of $X
(U)$ with the zero section of the tangent bundle of $U$ (\cite
{Bonatti92}); and as the the fixed-point index of the time-$t$ map of
the local flow of $X|U$ for sufficiently small $t> 0$.

(\cite{Dold72, Hirsch2014, Hirsch2015c}.)}

The celebrated {\sc Poincar\'{e}-Hopf} Theorem \cite{Hopf25,
  Poincare85} connects the index to the Euler characteristic
$\chi(M)$.  A modern formulation (see {\sc Milnor} \cite
{Milnor65})  runs as follows:

\begin{theorem*}[{\sc Poincar\'{e}-Hopf}]          {\label{{th:PH}}}

Assume $M$ is a compact $n$-manifold,$ X\in {\mathcal {V}} (M)$, and ${\ensuremath{\operatorname{{{\mathsf {Z}}}} (X)}}\cap {\ensuremath{\partial}}
M={\varnothing}$.  If $X$ is tangent to ${\ensuremath{\partial}} M$ at all boundary points, or
points outward at all boundary points then $i (X, M)=\chi (M)$.  If
$X$ points inward at all boundary points, $i (X, M)= (-1)^{n-1}\chi
(M)$.
\end{theorem*}

\noindent 
For  calculations of the index in  more general settings see  

{\sc Gottlieb} \cite{Gottlieb86}, 

 {\sc Jubin}  \cite{Jubin09},

{\sc  Morse}  \cite{Morse29}, 

{\sc Pugh} \cite{Pugh68}. 


\medskip

 The
$X$-block $K$ is {\em essential} if ${\mathsf {i}}_K (X)\ne 0$.   When this
 holds  every $Y\in {\mathsf {N}}_U (X)$ 
 has an essential block of  zeros in $U$ (Theorem \ref{th:stability}).
 If $M$ is a
 closed manifold (compact, no boundary) and $\chi (M)\ne 0$, the
 Poincar\'e-Hopf Theorem implies  ${\ensuremath{\operatorname{{{\mathsf {Z}}}} (X)}}$ is an essential
 $X$-block. 

C. Bonatti's proved a remarkable extension of the
Poincar\'{e}-Hopf Theorem to certain pairs of commuting analytic
vector fields on manifolds that need not be compact:

\begin{theorem*} [{\sc  Bonatti} \cite{Bonatti92}] {\label{{th:bonatti}}}

Assume ${\ensuremath{{\mathsf {dim}\,}}} M\le 4$ and ${\ensuremath{\partial}} M={\varnothing}$.  If $X, Y\in {\ensuremath{\operatorname{{{\mathcal {V}}}^\omega} (M)}}$ and $[X, Y]= 0$,
then ${\ensuremath{\operatorname{{{\mathsf {Z}}}} (Y)}}$ meets every essential $X$-block.\footnote

{``The demonstration of this result involves a beautiful and quite
  difficult local study of the set of zeros of $X$, as an analytic
  $Y$-invariant set.'' \quad---{\sc P.\ Molino} \cite{Molino93}}

\end{theorem*}

\noindent Related results  are in
the articles \cite{Bon-Sant15,  Hirsch2015a, Hirsch2015b, HW2000,
  Lima64, Lima65,  Plante91, Turiel03}. 

Our main result is an extension of Bonatti's Theorem:

\begin{theorem}      {\label{{th:MAINnew}}}

Let $M$ be a connected $3$-manifold and ${\mathcal {A}}\subset {\mathcal {V}}^{\omega} (M)$  an abelian
Lie algebra of analytic vector fields on $M$.  Assume  $X\in{\mathcal {A}}$ is
nontrivial and
${\ensuremath{\operatorname{{{\mathsf {Z}}}} (X)}}\cap {\ensuremath{\partial}} M={\varnothing}$.  If $K$ is
an essential $X$-block, then ${\ensuremath{\operatorname{{{\mathsf {Z}}}} ({\mathcal {A}})}}\cap K\ne\varnothing$.
\end{theorem}

\noindent 
The proof, in  Section \ref{sec:proof}, relies heavily on Bonatti's Theorem. 
An analog for surfaces is proved in  
{\sc Hirsch} \cite[Thm.\ 1.3] {Hirsch2015a}. 




\subsubsection{Application to attractors}   {\label{{sec:attrac}}}

The {\em interior} ${\ensuremath{\operatorname{\mathsf{Int}}}} (L)$ of a subset $L\subset M$ is the union of
all open subsets of $M$ contained in $L$.
 
Fix a metric on $M$.  If  $Q\subset M$ is closed, the minimum distance
from  $z\in M$ to  points of $Q$ is denoted by
${\mathsf {{dist}}}(z,Q)$. 

Let $X\in {\mathcal {V}}^1 (M)$ have local flow $\Phi$.  An {\em attractor} for
$X$ (see \cite{Akin93, Conley78, Hale88, Smale67}) is a nonempty
compact set $P\subset M$ that is invariant under $\Phi$ and has a
compact neighborhood $N\subset M$ such that
mathml: <math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.Ex1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\Phi_{t}(N)\subset(N)" display="block"><mrow><mrow><msub><mi mathvariant="normal">Φ</mi><mi>t</mi></msub><mo>⁢</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow><mo>⊂</mo><mrow><mo stretchy="false">(</mo><mi>N</mi><mo stretchy="false">)</mo></mrow></mrow></math>

<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E2.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="\par

nexttext:
\begin{theorem}         {\label{{th:attrac}}}

 Let $M$,  ${\mathcal {A}}$ and $X$ be as in {\em Theorem \ref{th:MAINnew}}.  If 
 $P\subset M$ is  a  compact attractor for  $X$ and   $\chi (P)\ne
 0$, then ${\ensuremath{\operatorname{{{\mathsf {Z}}}} ({\mathcal {A}})}} \cap P\ne\varnothing$.
\end{theorem}


\noindent
{\em Proof.}  $P$ is a proper subset of $M$--- otherwise $M$ is a
closed 3-manifold having nonzero Euler characteristic, an
impossibility (e.g.,\ {\sc Hirsch} \cite[Thm. 5.2.5]{Hirsch76}).  Fix
$N$ as above and note that $\chi (N)\ne 0$. 

 By (\ref{eq:N}) and Poincar\'{e}-Hopf Theorem there is an essential
 $X$-block $K\subset N\,\verb=\=\,{\ensuremath{\partial}} N$, and $K\subset P$ by
 (\ref{eq:limt}).  Standard homology theory and (\ref{eq:phitn}) imply
 that the inclusion map $P\hookrightarrow N$ induces an isomorphisms on
 singular homology, hence $\chi (N)=\chi (P) \ne 0$.

The conclusion follows from Theorem \ref{th:MAINnew} applied to the
data $M', {\mathcal {A}}', X'$:
mathml:
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1.m1" class="ltx_Math" alttext="N" display="inline"><mi>N</mi></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1.m2" class="ltx_Math" alttext="C^{1}" display="inline"><msup><mi>C</mi><mn mathvariant="normal">1</mn></msup></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1.m3" class="ltx_Math" alttext="X" display="inline"><mi>X</mi></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1.m4" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\partial}N" display="inline"><mrow><mo mathvariant="normal">∂</mo><mo mathvariant="italic">⁡</mo><mi>N</mi></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1.m5" class="ltx_Math" alttext="X_{p}" display="inline"><msub><mi>X</mi><mi>p</mi></msub></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1.m6" class="ltx_Math" alttext="{\partial}N" display="inline"><mrow><mo mathvariant="normal">∂</mo><mo mathvariant="italic">⁡</mo><mi>N</mi></mrow></math>
<math xmlns="http://www.w3.org/1998/Math/MathML" id="S0.E3.m1.m7" class="ltx_Math" alttext="p\in{\partial}N" display="inline"><mrow><mi>p</mi><mo mathvariant="normal">∈</mo><mrow><mo mathvariant="normal">∂</mo><mo mathvariant="italic">⁡</mo><mi>N</mi></mrow></mrow></math>

an open set $M\subset {\ensuremath{{\mathbb R}^{3}}}$ that contains  ${\ensuremath{\overline{B}}}_r$. 
Let $X\in{\mathcal {A}}$ and  $r >0$ be such

\begin{theorem}         {\label{{th:attrac}}}

 Let $M$,  ${\mathcal {A}}$ and $X$ be as in {\em Theorem \ref{th:MAINnew}}.  If 
 $P\subset M$ is  a  compact attractor for  $X$ and   $\chi (P)\ne
 0$, then ${\ensuremath{\operatorname{{{\mathsf {Z}}}} ({\mathcal {A}})}} \cap P\ne\varnothing$.
\end{theorem}


\noindent
{\em Proof.}  $P$ is a proper subset of $M$--- otherwise $M$ is a
closed 3-manifold having nonzero Euler characteristic, an
impossibility (e.g.,\ {\sc Hirsch} \cite[Thm. 5.2.5]{Hirsch76}).  Fix
$N$ as above and note that $\chi (N)\ne 0$. 

 By (\ref{eq:N}) and Poincar\'{e}-Hopf Theorem there is an essential
 $X$-block $K\subset N\,\verb=\=\,{\ensuremath{\partial}} N$, and $K\subset P$ by
 (\ref{eq:limt}).  Standard homology theory and (\ref{eq:phitn}) imply
 that the inclusion map $P\hookrightarrow N$ induces an isomorphisms on
 singular homology, hence $\chi (N)=\chi (P) \ne 0$.

The conclusion follows from Theorem \ref{th:MAINnew} applied to the
data $M', {\mathcal {A}}', X'$:

nexttext:
Case  I shows every finite subset of  $\mathfrak F$ has nonempty
intersection.  As $K$ is compact, all the elements of $\mathfrak F$
have nonmpty intersection, proving  ${\ensuremath{\operatorname{{{\mathsf {Z}}}} ({\mathcal {A}})}} \cap K\ne\varnothing$. \qed
